reviewText: A pretty good port of a pretty alright game. XIII-2 doesn't have the same level of polish that the first game has even though the port is much better thsi time around, meaning it has a very inconsistent difficulty level and some rather arbitrary mechanics, but the wide variety of new features, an overall improved battle system, and a still-stellar soundtrack make this a game worth playing for the price. The visuals are also spectacular in moments, particularly near the beginning and end, but a painfully padded middle-game really shows that they did not give nearly as much effort to the aethetics in the core of the experience. If you are able to get through a lot of the padding, you'll find a fun game with some moments on par with the high points in its predecessor, particularly the boss battles. Overall, though, the added visual options are a great touch and if you set your rig to maximize performance, you'll get some really smooth gameplay. While I have not played the entirety of the game on PC, I have completed it on PS3 and this review is based on my initial impressions. I will change them if anything significant lowers my opinion later on in the game.

reviewText:
I had just finished my live playthrough of the first one, and i'll say I loved every moment of it. I am a bit of the way in to this one and have to say a couple of things about it. The plot is pretty interesting, its not as epic and deep as the first but its good. The combat system has only been improved and expanded on. The leveling system is simplified to a more choose your class role rather than being forced into a couple of classes.

They have added a couple of things like summoned party members, monster synthesis and item crafting rather than just upgrading.

The cons though:

The game is lesser optimized. Even at the lowest settings my beast of a pc, while streaming, has frequent fps drops. Way worse than the first. It feels incredibly rushed in regards to optimization.

The plot isnt as powerful, yet still decent.

The world overall doesnt flow completely fluidly. The game feels very westernized. Which, to some people is probably a good thing. I dunno.

Overall I recommend the game, its a good and solid rpg but I HIGHLY recommend the first one first before you play this. You dont need to have played the first to enjoy this but it definitely deepens the universe when you know who the characters are and what the places are.

reviewText:
As much as I didin't like FFXIII, it at least had a satisfactory, conclusive ending. Unfortunately we now have a sequel that basically throws it out of the window, because FFXIII-2s main focus is time travel. Poorly done time travel that creates plot holes the size of Jupiter.

Throughout the game, you hop through several time periods to help unravel the overall story line. Unfortunately, this chopped narration left me confused on what the underlying tale was trying to tell. What is left is a jumbled, forced gibberish that some game designers called a story line. It also doesn't help that most of the plot is explained through long and uninteresting monologues, rather than actual cutscenes with dialogues. And when FFXIII-2 finally concludes with now infamous sequel-bait my only thought was Really?".

reviewText:
Being a truly dedicated fan of Square's franchises, (especially Final Fantasy) I sometimes am biased about my opinions. However, this really deserves a down to earth look at what's wrong here.

The game itself isn't bad. In fact it's above average by what I consider a fair standard for JRPG's coming westside recently. This game is simply a port of its console predesessor. And that is what I'm calling it through this review.

My PC's specs aren't high end, it's completely running on factory hardware. And I can play games such as Path of Exile and Call of Duty AW without much trouble, if any. And I'm running on 6 GB of RAM with an AMD A8 Quad-Core processor. Final Fantasy XIII ran almost PERFECTLY with very little chugging when the particles started flying. So as a PORT this game fails to meet what I would consider even sub-par standards that we've come to expect from an A-class company.

This game needs some serious patching. So if you're intending to buy this game, think hard about your rig's specs. This game may not hold up to your expectations, at least for now.

reviewText:
I'm in the unenviable position of having to bash one of my favorite JRPGs in recent memory: Final Fantasy XIII-2.  ... Well, the PC version anyways.  The console versions are still fantastic obviously.

I can't believe this.  Original FFXIII actually runs surprisingly well on my PC considering all the port issues, but FFXIII-2 runs like CRAP, even with the lowest possible settings (I freaking played FFXIII the day it launched on Steam and even then it ran WAY better than this).  There's got to be some bigger issues at play here as even people with very high-end graphics cards are reporting problems getting the game to run at a consistent framerate.  This is ridiculous, it's pretty much the same engine as FFXIII, and I remember it running a hair more smoothly than FFXIII on consoles, but it runs a whole heck of a lot worse here.

Well, hey, that's nearly 30GB of space I can get back on my PC at least, and I won't have to feel even the slightest temptation to get Lightning Returns when it inevitably comes out.  Glad I kept my PS3 copy.

Kind of a shame too, as Square-Enix frequently has PC sales, and the PC version includes most of the console DLC right out the gate (I think the only things not included are a few costumes and weapons and such, nothing major), plus the Japanese language track.

I hate to do this, as the game itself is wonderful, but I really can't recommend the PC version at all.  Blargh.

reviewText:
This game is unplayable at recommended specifications.

My computer isn't top of the line, but it's a few steps above the recommended specs for this game in all aspects.  I played through FFXIII on PC just fine; I don't expect a 60fps experience in 4k resolution, I expect for my somewhat dated but still capable hardware that I'm going to get framerate stutters, trouble animating several effects at once, and so forth.

In Final Fantasy XIII-2, at best I get 10fps during some battle scenes.  Cutscenes are a bleeding nightmare, as characters speak their lines and the game animates several frames very, very slowly as the dialogue pauses for it to catch up.  Running around on the map is around 3-6fps.  This is with all effects set to minimum and NVidia settings tweaked to maximize performance.

I'm fine with being told I can't play a game because my computer doesn't meet the specifications; I'm familiar with the minimum/recommended specs dance.  I don't expect great performance when I purchase a game where I overtop the recommended specs by a slight margin, I just expect something I can play through and experience.  FFXIII-2 does not currently meet this criteria.

This game is in need of patching to resolve frame rate issues, until then I cannot recommend it as I cannot play it.

reviewText:
I will recommend this game once they fix the horrendous FPS/stuttering issues. How is it possible that I can run NEW games on High to Ultra, yet get 9-30 FPS on this game, one from years ago? Not to mention the graphics are so fuzzy, it looks like somebody enabled FXAA antialiasing for a program that doesn't require it. Even using NVIDIA control panel to give a performance boost does ZERO to help increase FPS. Regardless of whether you play the game with x16 MSAA, or x2, you receive the same FPS. Same with the shadow quality slider option. If anything, it ran slightly smoother with maxed graphics quality than lesser. Not to mention the audio is all over the place. Voices are too loud in cutscenes, too soft everywhere else, and there is no in-game slider to balance it out. Once (or IF) patched and stabilized, it will be as much fun as it was for the PS3. If it doesn't receive the needed patches/updated optimizations, steer clear of this game for the PC.

[Updated - 12-16-2014]

After clearing the very first area, the fps improved by 10, which is apparently a huge deal for this particular game. Game is now playable at a constant 20-30 fps, with the only increase over that being 50-60 for menu/blank loading screens.

Idk what all was going on graphically in the first area, but it must have had some serious graphic drainers. Hopefully they patch this game eventually like how they did with FF13's fps stability update. Adding an ingame option to change the various sound levels would be nice too. However, now that I'm back to reliving the fun I had years ago on the PS3 version, I can thankfully change this to something I recommend.

reviewText:
I got to say, I was really skeptical going into this game, with all the negativity surrounding it, but I was pleasantly surprised by this game, I enjoyed it more than I expected. Almost every complaint towards FFXIII was addressed in this game:
-the combat system is almost the same as in FFXIII, but with great improvements.
-explorable towns, people to talk to and actual sidequests.
The graphics are really amazing considering it's a 2011 game, most of the locations are a sight to behold. The voice acting is excellent. The music is awesome, with a wide range of different tunes. The story may not be the best out there, but it's still fun.
All in all it's great experience.
The port isn't perfect, it doesn't maintain solid 60 fps, sometimes it will dip to 24~30, but still playable.

reviewText:
TL;DR: It feels like DLC turned in to a full game but there are major improvements/changes that make it interesting enough to warrent a purchase. The graphics seem worse than XIII yet the assets look like they were pulled directly from the previous game. The story is the weaker element, not as good as XIII yet the gameplay improved on everything that was annoying about XIII. It's a good title, it holds up as it's own game but it's not something that will keep you hooked.

(I jumped right in to XIII-2 just moments after finishing XIII so comparisons will be made between the two, this review will concentrate on the changes made from XIII to XIII-2 as the games are so similar that if you did like XIII then you will most likely enjoy this.)

It feels like DLC turned in to a full game, What i mean by this is that it feels like they had a cool idea to play as Serah in an expansion to XIII but opted to turn it in to it's own game, This is common in the industry (Just take a look at Saints Row 4, it was originally a DLC for Saints Row The Third)

With that being said  it IS a fun game to play though at first glance it is misleading, With Lightning's character model and face plastered all over the place it is easy for one to think that she is the focus of the game, she is in a sense but not in the playable kind, she is the starting focus of the story.

Serah is your playable character in this game, a long with a boy called Noel. Graphics wise it actually looks worse than the original XIII to me but that could be down to the port itself. Gameplay wise itis more of the same only they scrolled things back a bit in terms of enemy encounters.

You can no longer see the enemies in full view as you could in XIII, encounters work on a detection system where enemies will randomly appear as you are running around, you can either try to run or attack them. It's a sort of ballance between the way encounters worked in XIII and how encounters worked in the old school games.

The combat system as been revamped somewhat though it does feel a hell of a lot slower (even when using the haste ability) One of the major improvements is ability to switch party leader mid battle, this also means that the battle is not over if your current party leader goes down in battle, it simply switches to the next person so you can continue the fight.

The major update though is the addition of monsters, you can now Tame" monsters you encounter (Through no special mechanic
date: you simply beat a monster and sometimes it will drop a crystal wich adds that monster to your collection) These monsters act as your third party member in combat
recommended: each one having a specific role from the same pool of character roles that you saw in XIII.\n\nThese monsters can not become party leader and have the same behavior as any AI set in whatever role it happens to be in but with a unique twist. every monster has it's own special attack which can be used by incrasing the "Feral Link" gauge
hoursPlayed: this gauge works very similar to the "Gestalt" and "TP" gauge from XIII. Once full you can activate a special attack which then starts a QTE to determine a damage boost to said attack via a "Sync Level"\n\nHow fast you complete the QTE prompts determines your Sync percentage which determines the damage boost for the attack

reviewText:
A great sequel to FFXIII, that improves and expands on FFXIII in some terrific ways.

Pros:
• Better Plot: I found the story in FFXIII-2 to be easier to follow than FFXIII's plot.
• Less Serious Tone: More lighthearted moments throughout the story. Moogle had quite a few funny moments.
• Less Linear: There are multiple pathways in most levels with hidden loot.
• Less Grinding: The harder encounters are usually optional, so you don’t need to grind as much.
• More Freedom: Can choose where you want to travel to and what content you want to do.
• Dialogue Choices: A great addition, that was nonexistent in FFXIII.
• Great QTE Events: I usually hate QTEs but FFXIII-2 does a good job of making the QTEs feel appropriate, without overdoing it.
• Interesting DLC: Lightning and Sazh’s side stories were particularly engaging to play through.

Cons:
• Dull Side Quests: Quest design is not that interesting, and usually involves a lot of backtracking.
• Limited Characters: There are only 2 characters and 1 monster in your party. This is definitely a step back from FFXIII’s cast of 6 characters.

reviewText:
Part 2 of the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy starts off fast and gets right into things. The story is nicely carried over from the first XIII title and is generally presented pretty well. We return to familiar faces, along with some new ones.

The story starts off quite confusing and you are given tons of info pretty quickly. It may seem messy at first due to alot of unexplained events and the time travel aspect can mix things up a little further. However time travel in XIII-2 is mostly used as a way to get the game world to be opened up a bit and to move away from the linear direction that was FFXIII, from this point of view its done well and doesnt really pose any issues. As the story goes on it gets really intense, i found myself at the edge of my seat a few times.

The graphics for the most part seem to be slightly improved over the first game and are really enjoyable. The battle system is fantastic. Its simular to XIII with a bit of a twist with things like the mog clock, allowing you to start off a battle with haste if timed well. There is also the addition of pets and they act as the third member in your party. The Crystarium System is more streamlined and works really well.

The performance for some reason isnt as good as XIII and i find myself getting very varied frame rates, this should not happen on a 4000 dollar PC that was purchased in 2015. Overall its not too much of a problem, however it certainly doesnt go unnoticed and its worth mentioning. Hopefully they improve on this for Lightning Returns.

Boss fights feel very rewarding and fun. Encounter mechanics are fresh and interesting, this game has one of the most memorable final boss fights ive experienced in ages. There is a fair amount of grinding needed to be done to down the final boss but nothing too crazy, the progression feels right, they really nailed it here. There is a great addition of skins in XIII-2 that are taken to the next level in Lightning Returns, something that i rate very highly as i love customization in any game.

There is a lack of CG cutscenes in XIII-2 i would have liked a little more than the 2 or 3 they did for the game.

Overall i found FFXIII-2 to be a fantastic sequel that is a must play for anyone that enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII, you get the chance to delve further into Lightning and Serah's story, I cant wait to jump into Lightning Returns, this might be one of the best game trilogies ive played, infact this game was the reason i will continue to invest my time and money into the franchise and purchase a PS4 to contine the legacy that is Final Fantasy.

Would thank Square Enix again and again and again for porting this to PC.

9/10

First, let me tell you one thing:
I bought and went into this game expecting an exeptionally bad piece of software. What I got exceeded my expectations by a long margin. This game is - believe it or not - not that bad.

But first things first.

The Story.It is terrible. Just plain awful. Even if you thought the story of the first Final Fantasy XIII was fine and never left any questions unanswered, XIII-2's story will most likely go over your head. I have to admit, it lost me very early on. It kind of makes sense in the end, but then again...not really. Don't try to wrap your head around it.
It's not even the fact that it is about time travel, which in itself has always been one of the most confusing topics in movies and video games, no, it's just that the story writer went and took a rather simple concept and filled it with lots and lots of 'technobabbles' and weird pseudo-scientific assumptions to make it sound more complex than it actually is.

Some of the dialogues in this game reminded me of what it feels like to watch an episode of Star Trek.

reviewText:
Remember that like any modern Final Fantasy game, you may just hate it at first glance and I respect that decision.
TL;DR below.

Story-  This story is full of plot-holes and makes no sense.  Final Fantasy XII's story is a Godsend in comparison to this.  Imagine Final Fantasy XIII's story but with time travel that goes against all of the modern time travel conventions.  It is really only there to get the characters together for a new adventure.  You should not be playing this game for the story.

Exploration-  While still somewhat linear, there are hidden chests placed throughout the world that you can find.  You are also able to accept quests in the field.  Completion of these quests will cut down on grind time because they give you EXP (Crystarium Points).  You can travel between the different areas of the game in the Historia Crux, a menu showing all of the points of time you can travel to.  This menu allows you to reset areas, battling bosses again and gathering treasures you might have missed.  Enemies show up at random on the field, but you are given a short period of time to run away from them or get an early attack on them.

Combat-  In combat, you have a bar that is split into several segments that fills over time.  Battle commands can be attached to the segments of the gauge.  You can choose to use the entirety of your gauge at once, or use moves as the bar fills up.  Serah and Noel can be assigned classes and switch between these classes in combat.  This is where the meat of the battle strategy comes from.  You are able to have a Pokemon-esque monster accompany you in battle.  This monster also has a class which will help balance out your team.  The way the class system works still goes over my head, but I think that combat is enjoyable nonetheless.

Optimization- This game will run like garbage on YOUR PC.  I DON'T CARE IF YOU HAVE A TITAN X, THE GAME IS JUST BROKEN.  EXPECT 30 FPS AT ALL TIMES.

TL;DR, like most modern Final Fantasy games you will love it or you will hate it.  The story is meaningless, but the gameplay is enjoyable.

6.5/10 mediocre, would bluescreen while playing again.

reviewText:
I've always been a big fan of Final Fantasy games, even their most recent games. I've purchased VII, VIII, and XIII on Steam. the XIII games have had problems being ported so far, but the problems for XIII have been addressed for the most part, and it runs excellently! XIII-2 on the other hand, runs like a dead raccoon. There appear to be some CPU performance issues due to the game being a port from the PS3 version, with the abnormal CPU they put in that console. The game runs fine out in the world, the minimap instantly reduces fps from 60 to 30, disabling it boosts back to 60 right away. Upon opening the menu to equip items, change Paradigms, etc, the fps drops to a solid 20. I know that fps don't seem too important but with the amount of monsters to scroll through the low fps becomes a pain. Getting to the worst thing, in battle, I don't see fps higher than 15. Upon entering the battle, I have a solid 60 fps, but as soon as the battle menu HUD comes up, it drops and sits at 15, not going lower or higher than that. FFXIII menu also has an effect on fps, but not one this great. At 15fps most battles are not enjoyable, sounds seem lagged at that point and effects take a while to finish, I have attempted multiple fixes but have been unable to correct this problem. According to their specs, I should be able to run this game no problem, but that isn't the case.

Don't get me wrong, I love Final Fantasy games, no matter how different each installation may be, but this port in its current state is not worth your money. Save the 20$ until they either fix it, or you buy a thousand dollar intel processor to run it. Here's hoping they correct this problem so I can finish the game myself!

reviewText:
Part 2 of the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy starts off fast and gets right into things. The story is nicely carried over from the first XIII title and is generally presented pretty well. We return to familiar faces, along with some new ones.

The story starts off quite confusing and you are given tons of info pretty quickly. It may seem messy at first due to alot of unexplained events and the time travel aspect can mix things up a little further. However time travel in XIII-2 is mostly used as a way to get the game world to be opened up a bit and to move away from the linear direction that was FFXIII, from this point of view its done well and doesnt really pose any issues. As the story goes on it gets really intense, i found myself at the edge of my seat a few times.

The graphics for the most part seem to be slightly improved over the first game and are really enjoyable. The battle system is fantastic. Its simular to XIII with a bit of a twist with things like the mog clock, allowing you to start off a battle with haste if timed well. There is also the addition of pets and they act as the third member in your party. The Crystarium System is more streamlined and works really well.

The performance for some reason isnt as good as XIII and i find myself getting very varied frame rates, this should not happen on a 4000 dollar PC that was purchased in 2015. Overall its not too much of a problem, however it certainly doesnt go unnoticed and its worth mentioning. Hopefully they improve on this for Lightning Returns.

Boss fights feel very rewarding and fun. Encounter mechanics are fresh and interesting, this game has one of the most memorable final boss fights ive experienced in ages. There is a fair amount of grinding needed to be done to down the final boss but nothing too crazy, the progression feels right, they really nailed it here. There is a great addition of skins in XIII-2 that are taken to the next level in Lightning Returns, something that i rate very highly as i love customization in any game.

There is a lack of CG cutscenes in XIII-2 i would have liked a little more than the 2 or 3 they did for the game.

Overall i found FFXIII-2 to be a fantastic sequel that is a must play for anyone that enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII, you get the chance to delve further into Lightning and Serah's story, I cant wait to jump into Lightning Returns, this might be one of the best game trilogies ive played, infact this game was the reason i will continue to invest my time and money into the franchise and purchase a PS4 to contine the legacy that is Final Fantasy.

Would thank Square Enix again and again and again for porting this to PC.

9/10

reviewText:
A great sequel to FFXIII, that improves and expands on FFXIII in some terrific ways.

Pros:
• Better Plot: I found the story in FFXIII-2 to be easier to follow than FFXIII's plot.
• Less Serious Tone: More lighthearted moments throughout the story. Moogle had quite a few funny moments.
• Less Linear: There are multiple pathways in most levels with hidden loot.
• Less Grinding: The harder encounters are usually optional, so you don’t need to grind as much.
• More Freedom: Can choose where you want to travel to and what content you want to do.
• Dialogue Choices: A great addition, that was nonexistent in FFXIII.
• Great QTE Events: I usually hate QTEs but FFXIII-2 does a good job of making the QTEs feel appropriate, without overdoing it.
• Interesting DLC: Lightning and Sazh’s side stories were particularly engaging to play through.

Cons:
• Dull Side Quests: Quest design is not that interesting, and usually involves a lot of backtracking.
• Limited Characters: There are only 2 characters and 1 monster in your party. This is definitely a step back from FFXIII’s cast of 6 characters.

reviewText:
FFXIII-2 is such a good game that it almost makes me like FFXIII in retrospect. Almost.

First, let's just get the elephant in the room out of the way: yes, this port is terribly optimized. It may work fine for some, but I played at 30fps with drops, with is really pretty abysmal. The only thing this has over playing on console is resolution and the ability to use the Japanese audio. The Japanese audio, by the way, is fantastic.

So now on to the good. I played through FFXIII and really hated the experience by the end and still consider it the worst entry in the franchise. Then this game comes along and basically fixes every problem I had with the original.

Combat:
- Paradigm switching is now instant! A no brainer change, really, but it changes the pace of battle so much when you don't have to watch the camera stupidly focus in on every party member one at a time for each paradigm shift.

- You can now tame wild monsters and have them fight along side you. This not only goes a long way towards offering the player choice in how to compose their party early on, but it's also just a lot of fun finding badass or adorable monsters and taming them.

-The game just generally utilizes the game mechanics much more. I was forced to rapidly switch between paradigms and change up my party compositions SO much more than the original.

-Boss fights typically include QTE's to finish off the fight. Some might take issue with this but I liked them and it made beating bosses feel really satisfying. Reminded me of Bayonetta.

-Enemies no longer appear in the field all the time, but rather randomly show up in circle around you as you walk around. This isn't reeeaaally a positive or negative change, but what IS better is that you now have a dedicated attack button to get the drop on enemies instead of runnung around in circles like an idiot tryng to run into enemies from behind like in the original.

-Actually, there is a negative to be mentioned here: difficulty spikes. I have no problem with challenging games but when a section or boss comes out of nowhere and just wipes the floor with you repeatedly it tends to raise an eyebrow. This thankfully only happened to me twice (once in the middle, and then final batshit crazy boss), but it was more than a little annoying.

General Gameplay:
The original game had you do 2 things and 2 things only: walk forward and fight enemies. FFXIII-2 not only gets you up and running with all the game mechanics MUCH quicker, but generally has a greater amount of variety in it's gameplay, including:

- Actual sidequests! And lots of 'em!

- NPC's to talk to and interact with! Lots of those too!

- Branching pathways and areas that aren't a simple straight line!

- Monsters to tame and level up! Fight with a chocobo at your side!

- You have an adorable Moogle companion who you can throw (yes, throw) to reach far away treasure. A small but hilarious addition.

- The crystarium has been changed. It's still a pretty linear affair, but every time you fill up a full grid or screen or whatever, you can choose a big reward like adding a new section to the ATB guage or even unlocking a new role.

Story/characters/world:
- I was completely sick of most of the characters in FFXIII by the time I was through with it. Serah and Noel are, thankfully, handled in a much better fashion. I found Serah to be likeable from the get go,  and while her motivations aren't really that deep (I just want to see my sister again!") she's characterized really well and her sincerity is really charming. Then Noel is like FF's version of Riku
date: minus the being a d*ck to the main character part. Both have really solid voice acting whether playing in Japanese or English.\n\n- This game is also pretty dark
recommended: which might not be what you expect from looking at it. The farther and farther into the future you travel the more hopeless things become. This sense of desperation
hoursPlayed: to me
voteText: is the heart of Final Fantasy.\n\n- On a similar note
helpfulPercent: the time travelling is a lot of fun. Seeing how the world and characters change depending on what time period or even timeline they're in is really interesting. There's a good chance you'll get sick of hearing the word "paradox"
votesHelpful:
though. You've been warned.

Graphics/sound:
- The soundtrack is phenominal. The original certainly wasn't dragging it's feet in this department but I feel like it fell a bit short of pulling off a "different" sounding FF score. XIII-2 absolutely pulls it off. The three composers have put together an awesome collection of beautiful tracks ranging from the classic FF sounds
votesTotal: to some more electronically infused numbers and
votesFunny: best of all
commentsCount: a handfull of tracks that include vocals. The New Bodhum theme alone sets this score apart.\n\n- The game's a looker
column16: no doubt about that. Special mention goes to the animation however
column17: as I think Square is really great at animating their characters and especially faces.\n\nThere is one more negative however
column18: and that's how the game handles it's ending. To see the "real" ending you have to play a (thankfully included) DLC chapter that is incredibly tedious and feels entirely divorced from the whole experience. It's weird that Square would get such a huge amount of things right in this game and then bork up the delivery of the ending. Yeah. Just weird.\n\nThat aside
column19: I can't recommend this game enough. If you already liked the first
column20: then you robably didn't need any convincing anyway
column21: but if you are like me and hated the original
column22: then I have to urge you to give this one a shot. It's not often that a studio puts in this much effort into fixing a game

reviewText:
I will recommend this game once they fix the horrendous FPS/stuttering issues. How is it possible that I can run NEW games on High to Ultra, yet get 9-30 FPS on this game, one from years ago? Not to mention the graphics are so fuzzy, it looks like somebody enabled FXAA antialiasing for a program that doesn't require it. Even using NVIDIA control panel to give a performance boost does ZERO to help increase FPS. Regardless of whether you play the game with x16 MSAA, or x2, you receive the same FPS. Same with the shadow quality slider option. If anything, it ran slightly smoother with maxed graphics quality than lesser. Not to mention the audio is all over the place. Voices are too loud in cutscenes, too soft everywhere else, and there is no in-game slider to balance it out. Once (or IF) patched and stabilized, it will be as much fun as it was for the PS3. If it doesn't receive the needed patches/updated optimizations, steer clear of this game for the PC.

[Updated - 12-16-2014]

After clearing the very first area, the fps improved by 10, which is apparently a huge deal for this particular game. Game is now playable at a constant 20-30 fps, with the only increase over that being 50-60 for menu/blank loading screens.

Idk what all was going on graphically in the first area, but it must have had some serious graphic drainers. Hopefully they patch this game eventually like how they did with FF13's fps stability update. Adding an ingame option to change the various sound levels would be nice too. However, now that I'm back to reliving the fun I had years ago on the PS3 version, I can thankfully change this to something I recommend.

reviewText:
TL;DR: It feels like DLC turned in to a full game but there are major improvements/changes that make it interesting enough to warrent a purchase. The graphics seem worse than XIII yet the assets look like they were pulled directly from the previous game. The story is the weaker element, not as good as XIII yet the gameplay improved on everything that was annoying about XIII. It's a good title, it holds up as it's own game but it's not something that will keep you hooked.

(I jumped right in to XIII-2 just moments after finishing XIII so comparisons will be made between the two, this review will concentrate on the changes made from XIII to XIII-2 as the games are so similar that if you did like XIII then you will most likely enjoy this.)

It feels like DLC turned in to a full game, What i mean by this is that it feels like they had a cool idea to play as Serah in an expansion to XIII but opted to turn it in to it's own game, This is common in the industry (Just take a look at Saints Row 4, it was originally a DLC for Saints Row The Third)

With that being said  it IS a fun game to play though at first glance it is misleading, With Lightning's character model and face plastered all over the place it is easy for one to think that she is the focus of the game, she is in a sense but not in the playable kind, she is the starting focus of the story.

Serah is your playable character in this game, a long with a boy called Noel. Graphics wise it actually looks worse than the original XIII to me but that could be down to the port itself. Gameplay wise itis more of the same only they scrolled things back a bit in terms of enemy encounters.

You can no longer see the enemies in full view as you could in XIII, encounters work on a detection system where enemies will randomly appear as you are running around, you can either try to run or attack them. It's a sort of ballance between the way encounters worked in XIII and how encounters worked in the old school games.

The combat system as been revamped somewhat though it does feel a hell of a lot slower (even when using the haste ability) One of the major improvements is ability to switch party leader mid battle, this also means that the battle is not over if your current party leader goes down in battle, it simply switches to the next person so you can continue the fight.

The major update though is the addition of monsters, you can now Tame" monsters you encounter (Through no special mechanic
date: you simply beat a monster and sometimes it will drop a crystal wich adds that monster to your collection) These monsters act as your third party member in combat
recommended: each one having a specific role from the same pool of character roles that you saw in XIII.\n\nThese monsters can not become party leader and have the same behavior as any AI set in whatever role it happens to be in but with a unique twist. every monster has it's own special attack which can be used by incrasing the "Feral Link" gauge
hoursPlayed: this gauge works very similar to the "Gestalt" and "TP" gauge from XIII. Once full you can activate a special attack which then starts a QTE to determine a damage boost to said attack via a "Sync Level"\n\nHow fast you complete the QTE prompts determines your Sync percentage which determines the damage boost for the attack
voteText: each monster has it's very own unique attack each with different attributes.\n\nThe leveling system has also changed a fair bit

votesHelpful: rather than all roles having their own seperate progression track all roles are now on the same track which i honestly do prefer because "Builds" are now a viable option. The Crystarium also expands automatically rather than in key points of the story

reviewText:
First thing first: I would highly advise not playing this if you havent completed XIII already as while XIII is a game with serious flaws, the story of it will directly be spoiled in like the first half hour of this game.

On the whole, I enjoyed the game. There are some underlying flaws but it left me with a positive experience playing through to the end. The plot is very hard to follow, in that sometimes it just doesn't make sense. It's a time travel plot but where usually with this type of plot, you change the past and the future changes, here everything changes including the past, as well as having a location and character in the opening sequence that falls out of 'time' and you arent really sure whats going on. The good? It look's pretty, even if things don't make sense .

The battle system is probably the best disguise for a bad system I've seen in a long while. 'Auto Battle' command is back, which lets the CPU choose the best actions round by round. Personally I like to issue commands manually, only the thing is, to do so will put you at a huge disadvantage - manually issuing commands takes a couple seconds more while enemies still attack and prepare moves, and the commands are very generic (Attack, Magic attack, and four elements) for the most part. There are some battles with 6 enemies where I couldn't even tell what was going on, I found most battles I was glued to the HUD without looking at the graphics etc.

You control one character while the AI controls the other, as well as a tamed monster you can have. I disliked this system too - it had potential but did a bad job of explaining what monster stats were, what benefit using monster A over monster B was, or even the fact it doesnt flag 'rare' monsters you encounter in the field up so you can easily pass them by.

Character progression felt flat. You can level according to what you prefer, class wise, but by the end of the game you realise that in the end you will end up the same as every other player. As well, the points you put into the system to level up, dont seem to actually 'do' much. Partially realted to being glued to the HUD, you don't notice your characters scoring that massive crit thanks to their new stats/gear, because well, the numbers arent that impressive. Additionally the game seems to reward grinding and raw stats over strategy leaving many battles feeling unrewarding.

The game is not linear, one of the main complaints many had with XIII. Did they take it a bit too far here? Maybe. I would say no, overall, however the tools you use to unlock extra stages or unlock special skills, or heck to even advance, were very difficult to locate in levels without the assistance of a guide. I didn't have too much issue finding my way to the end of the game, but then going back and trying to unlock extra stages or locate and capture decent monsters is impossible to acheive in any sort of decent time without a guide.

Performance wise, it is a bad port, but with a few tweaks it is bearable, even fine if you have a good specced PC (I run it on an i7, GTX 770, and aside from a few frame rate drops it has been fine after tweaking using nvidia's own graphics settings.) There are no meaningful graphics settings in the games menu, so first thing you will want/need to do is google up some reccomended settings and then change these directly in your GFX cards manufacturers tool.

Expect to get around 30 hours from the main story, and exploring side branches of the story reasonably well. Post game, FF fans may expect an uber boss, there are a few in this however as mentioned before, to even set about finding them, or preparing for them, you need a guide. If I'm using a guide to do everything I don't see the point in doing it, so I will likely complete some of the DLC and retire from the game. Overall the 30 hours have been enjoyable and I felt I have definately got my moneys worth,

All hail Final Fantasy XIII-2, the first video game I've played where the HUD is the sole source of my low FPS.

reviewText:
One of my favorite FFs so far, which was totally unexpected since the reviews seemed mixed and I didn't like XIII that much.

Good:
- Attention to detail with the plot, which makes a lot of efforts to appear coherent and is a lot more memorable than the one from XIII (which is basically a lenghty ultra linear quest which made no sense and lead nowhere). Of course, it's a time paradox based story so you'll find as many plot holes as you want to, but I'd say the writers watched a lot of Doctor Who and it looks decent enough to be enjoyed.
- The main paradox in the story is just great, with a Doctor Who style resolution. Awesome.
- Real choices with corresponding alternate endings which make sense. And it's a way to escape your doom if you understand the problems with what the main characters are doing ...
- The two main characters are annoying and mean good but don't really know what they are doing. Clever. Lightning on the other hand is the best character from the XIII series by far, and they found a nice way to keep her busy while making her look good.
- Good combat system, slightly improved from XIII.
- The way the side content is blended with the main story (you have to do side missions at some points in the story, explore timelines a bit randomly, etc).
- Lots of side timelines and additional missions.
- Lots of content.

Bad:
- Could use a few more locations and one or two major paradox plots in the main story.
- Some important side content is gratuitously hard to find without guides (wild artefacts locations ...).
- Too grindy to complete the endgame content.
- Confusing character advancement (read guides).
- The third character in the party are monsters which can be swapped. Nice, but again too grindy and impossible to use correctly without reading wikis and guides. Although they tried to find something original and it's a decent attempt, a regular character would have been better.
- Graphics and textures are a big downgrade from XIII. Less budget (but far better game).
- Some technical details.

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game and I did have fun but when carying the FF name you get held to a higher standard. Here are my pros and cons.

Pros:
Fun high paced style very different from previous FF games.
Great animations and environments.
Lots of freedom to explore and extra challenges to face.
Good voice acting and excelent music.

Cons:
QTE finishers on boss monsters. I hate QTE sequences I'm sure some people love them just not for me.
No limit breaks. Your monsters get limit breaks which can be mildly powerful but your characters don't get them they get these ♥♥♥♥♥♥ super spells that can only be used once a fight and do only slightly more damage than normal moves.
Auto attacking is more effective than trying to cue up abilities manually. The fighting is too fast to navigate the menus and select the ideal combos (especially if you are hasted in a boss fight) and auto select does a decent job so why even bother?
Only having two people is novel but I didn't like it. Requires grinding areas for rare monster crystals which could take tens of hours if you're unlucky.
Story is hard to follow even for a time travel game.
Limited customization in character leveling. (again only two characters and they can be maxed out pretty quick)
No crafting or ultimate weapons.
Capacity limit or status ailments makes good gear worse (better to stack delicate low level items for synergy bonus).
Repetitive zones. It's cool you can go to the same place at different ages but it's the exact same map you play though 3 sometimes 4 times.
No new monsters or bosses. Same exact monsters and abilities and differet time periods have the same mobs just a different color pallet.
No fun mini games. The casino is dull the poker can only be played after the game is beaten and even then the opponents are predictable and no fun to play against. Slot machines are worthless.
Ending sucks. No spoilers just know that the ending along with pretty much all the Pardox Endings are sh*tty.

Final verdict.

It was fun and I did throw a bunch of hours into the game collecting almost all the fragments and getting the various endings but the poor story, poor character development, and lame ending are all major turn offs. Get it if you are a major FF fan (though you would probably already have played it by now) or it's on a significant sale.

reviewText:
After finally finding fixes for the issues I was having, I can now easily recommend this game. I'm not stingy about framerate, so playing this game at a steady, unmoving 30fps feels really nice, in comparison to the wonky 10fps-60fps I was having with the framerate unlocker.

Here's what I did: I first tried the framerate unlocker, which, as I said, was giving me some rather inconsistent framerate, among several other issues such as lip-sync going off. After that, I used a program called Nvidia Inspector (there's another program called RadeonPro for AMD cards) to limit my framerate to 30fps and v-sync to 1/2 refresh rate. My game was working perfectly after that, though the rain glitch still existed. After picking up the fix for that, I can enjoy the game fully, completely, how it was intended to be played.

If you follow those steps, this PC port is definitely the best version of the game. Coming with most of the console version's DLC, and now with Japanese audio (which in my opinion, is vastly superior to the English audio), this game is a great experience that improves upon the original XIII in every way I can think of. While I haven't beaten it yet, the story is great so far, with interesting characters, good graphics, fun gameplay, ear-♥♥♥♥♥♥ic soundtrack, and fantastic atmosphere. I can see why Famitsu gave this game a 40/40, it's rather incredible.

The XIII series is criminally underrated by fans" of Final Fantasy
date: but if you like JRPGs with high production values and go in with an open mind (the story isn't told to you completely

As the middle chapter of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy, I considered this game a must play after finishing FF 13. Final Fantasy 13-2 is the story of Serah, Noel, and the Time Rangers. Time is broken and it's up to them to solve history. As Time Travel stories go, I've seen worse and more confusing ones.

13-2 gets going right out of the gate in stark contrast of FF 13 which took about 10 hours before it opened up.  In this game, you can explore right from the the start.

The combat system is the same paradigm system from the first game with the added touch of monster taming. Tamed monsters fight with you in battle as part of your paradigms and, most monsters in the game can be tamed;each coming with their own active and passive benefits. Taming  monsters became my thing as I sought out and farmed specific monsters to add to my party.

The combat system never got boring, the story kept me interested until the end, and the monster farming added a fun side thing to do. Sure this is a Jrpg ♥♥♥ jrpg and got anime AF at times. But that's pretty much what I was expecting from a Final Fantasy game.  Some people on here were griping about the frame rate, but, I never experienced any FPS issues.  Worth the purchase.

This game also has a primer that tells the story of Final Fantasy 13 very well so you can skip the first game and not feel that you missed out on anything.

Played on a Toshiba Satellite

i5-3337u
740m 2GB
12GB Ram

Played on medium/high settings with no noticable frame rate issues.

reviewText:
+ Music is good
+ Graphics are fine

- Combat system is boring or annoying, it is very simple hence why they did it in real time, however when you need some specific actions to be done, you are basically sent straight to hell since there is no way to pause the game while you browse the various menus
- You cannot create your own party and you are stuck with the same 2 characters
- You can tame monsters... however the varieties are very limited
- Progression system is horrible, everything is automatically selected for you. Everything has been made so that it is impossible for you to accidently screw up your game hence why it does not take much brain.
- Story is okay-ish, however there is a lots of little points which just felt like they were fixed together without any proper thoughts.
- Dialogs / Interactions often include choices which are absolutely meaningless
- Cinematics have quick time events.
- They tried to randomized the encounter by spawning the monsters right into your face but this is just as bad and can create issues are times.
- The game crashed due to Steam cloud, fixed it by disabling it for the game but these kind of thing should simply not happen on a finished product.

Please do yourself a favor and play Chrono Cross, Star Oceans or probably any other RPGS instead of wasting your time on this game. I already poured a lot of time to learn the various aspects of the game since they don't unlock everything for you straight away and I will probably continue until I have finished this game since I like to complete what I start however let me tell you that it is far from being fun. The game doesn't even need grinding and that's usually the bad parts of JRPGS.

reviewText:
This game is similar to FF13, but it has no boring linear grind.  Furthermore, it has one of the most interesting combat systems I have played.  The hook is the endless possibilities of your third party member/pet.  Since nearly all non-boss enemies can be captured, leveled, and customized through transferring skills, most of my fun came from just working with the recruited enemies.  On Steam is the second time I'm playing through this game.  If the story is extremely crucial, you may somewhat enjoy this game.  If the combat system is crucial to you, this game is worth a shot!

Story: 7/10  -I was only interested in bits of it.
Combat: 10/10  -The best aspect of the game.
Characters: 7/10  -Somewhat less annoying than the original.
Music: 7/10  -Many scores are weird, but some rock!
Controls: 10/10  -Good controller support.
Open Feel: 9/10  -Takes about 1-2 hours to get it to feel more open.
Side Story Goals: 10/10  -There are interesting side aspects to take your mind off the grind.

Last thought!  It plays great and looks pretty good on my Surface Pro 3!  Portable full game!  Awesome!

reviewText:
Overall Review: 8.5

Graphics: 9
Sound: 8
Story: 8
Fun: 9
Difficulty: 9.5
Controls: 8

Here is my review and opinions on this game. Overall I really enjoyed playing this game, and am still building up the monster's for fun! If you like RPG's you will probably like this game. It might help to know the previous story in 13 but honestly I had to re read most of it again since it's so complicated at times so really you can jump in at this game I think.

You'll find the graphics are nice and the animations are good, its overall a very nice game to listen to and play but its not a very good FF game. Meaning that because its has FF in the front of its title its supposed to blow the doors off of the ride. Its just not that good.

So if you like rpg's you'll find the game to be a mix of chrono trigger with time travel and tomb raider with exploration and finding VERY hard to find fragements that are shaded dark and transparent so have fun with that without a guide!

The rest of the difficulty is just navigating the huge world where i feel it can slow the pacing. Old final fantasy games would frustrate me with the amount of battles and lack of story progress where as here the sheer size of the worlds to travel can take up time. there are chocobo's to speed things up but still... some maps are needlessly big. A common square enix complaint of mine. To much world not much interaction.

The music is good but for its ups it has downs, i wouldn't play the ost front to back but playlist about half of it. Nice though overall.

The battle system is where its at. This time you have only two character's,  aa bold rpg move, but you have a rotating monster to fill the third spot, this is fun but they are usually kinda weak untill late game so its helpful but sort of lacking as a real team member.

The story is cool but why is time travel just now making an appearance in FF13 series? I don't think this is really all bad but it makes the world seem contrived and its just an odd feeling of the series being not a very well defined and formed rpg.

They just make these ff games ont the fly these days without much real originality. Its a very manufactured rpg for your enjoyment but that's like a person who tries hard to be your friend and makes thier life choices around you. I would rather know they had a personality that was original and that I liked them... anyways i respect that they made improvements based on what we didn't like in 13... but why did they need to? Shouldn't they just make a good FF game that we are used to? Since 10 (the last true FF in many's opinion) its been all over the place and honestly just play this game as an RPG and put up with the Final Fantasy in the title as just a title not the gameplay hint.

Sad but true, its still a good RPG and i reccoment it. Its very fun but very hard and the story is different but interesting albeit with very few actual characters. Most places have people in the towns but its not like they really are that interesting in my opinion. I feel like this is a very KOTOR Final Fantasy actually but that could just be me.

If you like RPG's and action turn based combat get this one, its fun overall! If you like FF6 religiously try to take it in stride!

reviewText:
This game is terribly optimized.

I knew it was bad, but since I can run another poorly optimized game (TERA) and as I can run most recent games like DS2 and Skyrim with high settings just fine, I thought that I could stand some framerate dips.

So I wait 6 hours for this to download over a slow internet connection, and I start the game. Cutscenes and menus look fine. The first tutorial battles run at a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 20 fps, but at least it's playable.

But then -- The game officially starts and puts me in control of my character. And it was like I was trying to run it on a toaster.

COMPLETELY UNPLAYABLE. I'm talking 5 fps. I don't understand why this game underutilizes both CPU and GPU so badly? I've scoured the internet for fixed, but it seems like I have wasted money on a game I can probably never play because I can't clock my CPU high enough to get it to a playable state.

Is my CPU the best? No. But it fits the minimum reqs and it can run other recent games at buttery smooth framerates so I don't understand why I can't get at least a solid 30 in the beginning of the game, inside a small house, with no other characters on screen.

1/10 at least the pre-rendered cutscenes are pretty

EDIT: so I cranked all the settings down to the bare minimum and changed the power settings for this game in Nvidia Control Panel to maximum performance. This made it playable @ 30+ fps with some drops, but it's still a shame that it's so poorly optimized.

Will update rating when I actually play through the game.

reviewText:
DO NOT PURCHASE THE PC VERSION OF THIS GAME... YOU ARE MUCH BETTER OFF GETTING A USED COPY OF THIS GAME ON A XBOX 360 OR PS3 CONSOLE FOR CHEAP INSTEAD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!


Note; I am not writing a negative review towards the game itself. From what I played so far with my few hours in this version, it's actually quite GREAT!! Obviously, the game takes place after the events of the Final Fantasy XIII and takes the original concept of XIII's game play and well... Pretty much sets it on fire.

It throws away the linearity seen in the original and makes it entirely open and free to explore (although personally I didn't mind linearity at all.. And imho it actually fits the stories theme but that's just my personal preference.) as well as adding some new features to what's an already great combat system... One of the new features being is that you can now have POKEMON ON YOUR TEAM!!! ...erm, I mean monsters of course...

BUT....
There is just one thing wrong with this...
IT'S THE PORT OF THIS GAME.. IT’S GOD AWFUL!!!!!!!!!!!

I was able to run the original game just fine with some minor issues here and there, but nothing too serious and was an overall enjoyable experience for me. However with this game, it runs terrible even though graphically the game is NOT any different as the orginal!! I keep on getting CONSTANT frame rate drops left and right, yet when I explore in some areas the frame rate runs buttery smooth. IT MAKES NO SENSE???

Not only that, but the port also LACKS graphic options. The only options are just resolutions and anti-aliasing. SERIOUSLY!?!?

This port is so bad that I had to download patches for the game that was made by the community, but even then the game still ran terrible. I understand that porting console games onto the PC is no easy task, but seeing this coming out from SE, this is unacceptable.

I had to watch a movie" version of this game onto YouTube instead
date:
and it really made me sad seeing as how I'll never get the chance of actually playing this game.. Which is a huge let down.

What's even worse is that this port has been out for an ENTIRE YEAR... AND SE HAS DONE NOTHING ABOUT IT!!!!

Like I said
recommended: just get the console version of this game

reviewText:
This game is amazing. The battle system is almost the same as 13. but has added monster training as a third party member instead of another character. They also introduced dialogue options. Overall the level design is much better as they are way less linear and more interesting. Not to mention there is time travel and a ton of sidequests and alternate paradox endings to explore and find. The game has way more replayability than 13 and is a pretty big improvement on an already great game. English voice acting is still bad so I reccomend setting Japanese audio in the launcher.

The ONLY DOWNFALL of this game is severe framedrops. Overall during battle my game plays @60fps but some specific cutscenes where 10fps. Most cutscenes and exploration played at 40-60 fps with a lot of fluxuations. And there is a mod/patch someone made but it actually makes the framerate worse in some areas and some areas it does nothing. Also I have to get a patch for an Xbox One controller to work, but 13 had the same problem as well. (that's not too big of a deal though)

I honestly don't mind the optimization issues becasue its a great game either way, and honestly it probably still runs at a hgher framerate than the console versions so it's better in that aspect anyways.

reviewText:
Bought this back on the PS3 when it first came out but couldn't get into it. Tried it again a few years later, pushed past the slightly dull opening few hours and now can't put it down. It's an interesting concept: travelling through time to try to change history, visiting alternate versions of the same places on different timelines - as well as the obligatory 'save the world' theme. Sure, it still has that slght repetitiveness that FFXIII had, but this time the world at least feels more open and not so much a 'walk down this corridor and fight lots of enemies ad infinitum' feel that its predecessor had.

I know there are meant to be issues with the port, and my FPS fluctuates wildly between 20-60 all the time, but I can't say I've actually noticed any difference when it does (i.e. lagging or screen-tearing), so can't comment on the actual issues themselves.

All in all, this is a more interesting game than FFXIII (minus some of its most interesting characters in Lightning and Fang, for me) and I'm looking forward to completing it so I can finally play 'Lightning Returns'. Even if you got bored of XIII, I'd recommend giving this a go, especially for the sale price.
